name: Tamarind Rice (Puliyodarai)
history: Tamarind Rice, also known as Puliyodarai, is a traditional South Indian dish. It's a popular offering in temples and a staple in many households. The dish is known for its tangy and spicy flavor, derived from the use of tamarind and various spices.
description: Tamarind Rice is a flavorful dish made with cooked rice mixed with a tangy and spicy tamarind paste. This paste is prepared with tamarind, spices, and dal. It's a delightful mix of sour, spicy, and savory flavors, commonly served during festivals and special occasions.

instructions.title: Prepare Tamarind Paste
instructions.description: Soak tamarind in warm water, extract the pulp. Heat oil in a frying pan, add mustard seeds, urad dal, chana dal, dry red chilies, asafoetida, curry leaves, and peanuts. Fry until dals turn golden. Add tamarind pulp, turmeric powder, jaggery, fenugreek seeds, coriander seeds, and salt. Cook until the mixture thickens.

instructions.title: Mix with Rice
instructions.description: In a large bowl, mix the cooked rice with the prepared tamarind paste. Ensure the rice is evenly coated.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Tamarind Rice warm. It can be accompanied by yogurt or papad.

tips: Ensure the tamarind paste is well-cooked and thickened for the best flavor.
Adjust the quantity of jaggery and red chilies to balance the tanginess and heat.
variations: Add roasted cashews for a crunchy texture.
Include green peas or grated carrots for added nutrition and color.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in a microwave or on a stove until warm.
presentationTips: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves or lemon slices for a fresh look.
Serve in traditional South Indian dinnerware for an authentic experience.
